top10.hook: How is it possible that all these members of congress are worth millions of dollars on a salary of just 174,000? I'll give you a hint. It's not speaki
top10.fullTranscript: How is it possible that all these members of congress are worth millions of dollars on a salary of just 174,000? I'll give you a hint. It's not speaking fees. They do it by trading stocks. Let me give you an example. Back in November, I noticed that congresswoman Debbie Wasserman bought shares at a company called Viasat. For those who don't know, Viasat is a satellite internet provider who also happens to do a ton of business with the US military. Now, the reason this stood out to me at the time is because Debbie Wasserman isn't just your average congresswoman. She just so happens to sit on the house subcommittee on military construction. What this means is that she sits on closed door meetings learning about all sorts of new military contract discussions that are completely closed off to the public. The fact she bought shares in ViaSat, a major defense contractor, while attending these meetings told me that maybe she knows something about ViaSat that we don't. And sure enough, fast forward just one month later, NASA announced a 4,820,000,000.00 contract for low Earth orbit satellites in which one of the companies awarded was, yep, you guessed it, ViaSat. And since I made that post about Debbie buying ViaSat in November, shares are up more than 40%. Now I wish I could say that this was an isolated incident, but the truth is this happens all the time. And it's the reason that until they outlaw trading in congress, you should be tracking what they're buying and selling. Because maybe they know something that we don't. To track congress trades and government contracts, check out Quiver Quan where I track it all live.

top10.hook: What the Like, how are they allowed to do it when other Americans can't? Sunny Santa Monica, California, seemingly a world away from Washington DC, is
top10.fullTranscript: What the Like, how are they allowed to do it when other Americans can't? Sunny Santa Monica, California, seemingly a world away from Washington DC, is where we found Chris Joseph's and his different morning routine. Every day, Chris wakes up, makes a cup of coffee, and then alongside fellow Internet sleuths sifts through the stock trades members of congress make. It all started off as infuriating because it's you're like, what the Like, how are they allowed to do it when other Americans can't? As long as a trade is reported before forty five days, there's no law preventing members of the house or senate from trading stocks. Outraged at first, Chris then saw an opportunity to get in on the action. He moved out west and with three friends launched the app autopilot. It lets users follow a politician's trades and then copy them, automatically buying or selling the same stock a lawmaker does at whatever dollar amount they like. That's where the money is? Yeah. The reason why we initially set out with the politicians is because they were killing They were killing it. They were killing it. Yeah. They were making a lot of money. You're trying to get in on the money? I'm trying to get in on the money. Yep.

top10.hook: Follow me down the rabbit hole of how I figured out a senator thinks he's above the law, and there's nothing you or I can do about it. I got a tip the
top10.fullTranscript: Follow me down the rabbit hole of how I figured out a senator thinks he's above the law, and there's nothing you or I can do about it. I got a tip the other day telling me I should look into a bill in congress right now called s forty ninety. This caught my eye because what the bill effectively wants to do is add regulations to the sale of vitamins and supplements, which would essentially make it illegal to sell any that don't comply with a costly approval process. And if cheap, over the counter vitamins are outlawed, it's easy to see how pharmaceutical companies would stand to benefit. The reason I'm telling you this is that the main sponsor of the bill is senator Richard Durbin from Illinois. And, of course, the first question in my head when I read the bill was, has he bought any pharmaceutical stocks recently? Because if he did, it would be a clear conflict of interest. Right? But after a good thirty minutes of looking, I couldn't find a single stock transaction that he's reported. Now this is weird because the law clearly states that if you're in congress, you have to disclose any financial transactions above $1,000 within forty five days. Eventually, I figured out that Richard Durbin, who, mind you, has been a senator for ten years now, has yet to file a periodic stock trade disclosure once. And it's not like he's not trading. Files annual financial reports, and in them, I can see him moving hundreds of thousands of dollars around. But as far as posting them regularly, like the law says, he has never done it once. I've tried reaching out to his office and the people who work for him, but haven't received a single reply. So if you take away anything from what I said, it's this. We don't know if Richard Durbin is gonna benefit if he gets the bill passed financially, but we should have the right to know. And the fact that he's blatantly disregarded financial laws for over ten years and nothing has happened should concern every American. Follow for more, and thanks for watching.

top10.hook: No. This is not true at all. This is like a complete Republican fabrication. It is December 20 '24. Members of Congress have to file financial disclos
top10.fullTranscript: No. This is not true at all. This is like a complete Republican fabrication. It is December 20 '24. Members of Congress have to file financial disclosures. And you can see from my legal disclosures, that I remain one of the lowest net worth members of congress. To AOC's credit, what she's saying is true. Out of almost 500 congress members, she's six from the bottom when ranked by net worth and hasn't traded single stock since being in office. The reason I can say that is because I'm willing to bet I know the net worth of members of congress better than most of them know themselves. That's because once a year, US politicians have to disclose every single asset that they have that's worth more than $1,000. This made me curious, so what I did was take it a step further, and wrote code that tracks the value of their assets and updates it live daily. The results look like this. The live net worth of hundreds of politicians and how much they made or lost on any given day. And hear me out, I didn't do this because I'm trying to be nosy. I did it because now I can go back and look at this list, see who's performing well at any point in time, and then click on their profile and see if they have any investments that I might want to copy. For instance, right now I can see that Thomas Swazi has made $82,000 in the stock market today. And when I click on his profile, I can see how his investments have done over time, see the composition of his portfolio, and see if there's any stocks holding that stand out to me. I made it public, no counter paywall required, because at the end of the day, the more eyes on this stuff, the better. So if you want to check it out, just look up Congress Live Net Worth Tracker on Google, and it's the first result. Good luck, and until next time.
